title: Where does African American culture come from? - Quora
tags: Culture of the United States of America

response.answer_text: 1513 - Thirty Africans accompany Balboa on his trip to the Pacific Ocean. 1518 -King Charles I of Spain grants the first licenses to import enslaved Africans to the Americas.-enslaved Africans, considered to be the first in the present-day United States, arrive, These Africans flee the colony, however, and make their homes with local Indians1607 - Jamestown is founded - About 20 blacks from a Dutch slaver are purchased as indentured workers for the English settlement of Jamestown. These are the first Africans in the English North American colonies. 1624 it is believed that The first African American child born free in the English colonies, William Tucker, is baptized in Virginia. - 1625 The first enslaved Africans arrive in the Dutch Colony of New Amsterdam (now New York City) with the Dutch West India Company. They quickly become the city's first municipal labor force, clearing the land of timber, cutting lumber, cultivating crops, and constructing roads and fortifications. 1634 slavery is introduced in Maryland. 1641-Massachusetts permits the slavery of Indians, whites, and Negroes in its Body of Liberties. It is the first mainland British colony to legalize slavery. 1642 - Virginia passes a fugitive slave law. Offenders helping runaway slaves are fined in pounds of tobacco. An enslaved person is to be branded with a large R after a second escape attempt. 1645 Dutch colonists transfer some of their landholdings in New Amsterdam to their former enslaved Africans as compensation for their support in battles with Native Americans. A condition of the land transfer, however, is the guarantee of a specified amount of food from those lands to their former owners. 1660 -A Connecticut law prohibits African Americans from serving in the militia. 1662 - Virginia reverses the law so that the child follows the status of his father, and enacts a law that makes the free or enslaved status of children dependent on the status of the mother. 1663 -Maryland slave laws rules that all Africans arriving in the colony are presumed to be slaves. Free European American women who marry enslaved men lose their freedom. 1682-New York enacts its first slave codes. They restrict the freedom of movement and the ability to trade of all enslaved people in the colony. 1688-Quakers in Germantown, Pennsylvania denounce slavery in the first recorded formal protest in North America against the enslavement of Africans. 1694 The success of rice cultivation in South Carolina encourages the importation of larger numbers of enslaved laborers especially from Senegal and other rice-producing regions of West Africa.1695 -Rev. Samuel Thomas, a white cleric in Charleston, South Carolina, establishes the first school for African Americans in the British North American colonies. 1700 -Samuel Sewall's The Selling of Joseph, is considered the first major condemnation of slavery in print. 1712 -The New York City slave revolt begins on April 6. Nine whites are killed - 21 slaves are executed. 1737 - An indentured black servant petitions a Massachusetts court and wins his freedom after the death of his master. 1738 - The first permanent black settlement in what will become the United States is established by fugitive slaves at Gracia Real de Santa Teresa de Mose (Fort Mose), Florida. 1739 -The first major South Carolina slave revolt takes place in Stono on September 9. A lot of whites and more than twice as many black slaves are killed as the armed slaves try to flee to Florida. 1739-Nineteen white citizens of Darien, Georgia petition the colonial governor to continue the ban on the importation of Africans into the colony, calling African enslavement morally wrong. 1775 - the first abolitionist meeting in North America is held. 1775 to 1781 - After the War of Independence Approximately 450,000 enslaved Africans comprise 20% of the population of the colonies at the time of the Declaration of Independence. 1776 A passage in the Declaration of Independence condemned the slave trade. The passage is removed from the Declaration due to pressure from the southern colonies. 1777-Vermont becomes the first political jurisdiction in the United States to abolish slavery.

I am certain there are Quorans far better qualified to answer this question. But as far as I can tell, African-American culture is at root a consequence of West African cultures meshing with parts of White Southern (British-based) cultures within the turbulent environment of American slavery. Various cultural memes—ranging from how some people pronounce the word “water”, to fried chicken, to rhythm/percussion-based music—are obviously the result of the clash between those two worlds. Way back in the day, Scottish people cooked fried chicken, but left it very bland. Then later brought that tradition to the American South. Black slaves put their twist on the dish. Now we call fried chicken Soul/Southern cuisine. European music was once more melodic than percussive, while African music often focused on complex rhythm and drums. Hence, Black/American popular music (jazz, blues, contemporary gospel, soul, hip-hop). There are numerous examples like this, which in my opinion, reinforce my beliefs about the origins of Black American culture.
